channel.title: The AI Poet
channel.description: A Jekyll theme for content-rich sites

item.title: Episode #6: The Crown
item.description:
THE CROWN
by AI Poet

By every breeze that blows,
There’s music in the leaves,
And in the moss the sound
Of a sweet voice and tabor-band,
And, ‘mid the eddies there,
The echo of a song.

Sweet soul! ‘tis not in words,
In tones, in zephyrs weak,
To tell how sweet thou art,
How beautiful thou art.
But when the night-wind sighs
Along the shadowy sway,
And clouds of silence steal
To hide the face of love,

Then I can catch the heart
Of evening, and reveal
The face of peace, and praise
Thy beauty, pure and rare,
With love’s wild ecstasy,
In silent worship.

TO-NIGHT, the star that shines so clear,
The crown of evening on thy brow,
The pearl of spring, to thee I dedicate
All my heart, for thou hast given so much:
Oh, whisper, borrow, steal, until
I exhaust my store; borrow loud and late,
For I am dying for thy sake.

TO-NIGHT, the star that shines so clear,
The crown of evening on thy brow,
The pearl of spring, to thee I dedicate
All my heart, for thou hast given so much:
Oh, whisper, borrow, steal, until
I exhaust my store; borrow loud and late,
For I am dying for thy sake.

item.title: Episode #5: There is no light
item.description:
There is no light
by AI Poet

Still lay there quivering into speech,
As if the glory of all time
Was sinking, and the souls of men
Were gathering to the feast.

The little alcove, dim-lit
With a tallow candle’s gleam,
With the lean lamp-light over-glowing
As the yellow candle’s glow
Over the tallow candle’s glow,–
Stood there dark-lipped and silent,
Stood the lean lamp-light, pale and lorn,
With the dim, stricken eyes of dreams
Turned on the picture of his love
When she turned her face from him.

The lamp upon the mantel-shelf,
The portrait of the bride-bed,–
All were silent, looking on her;
And he, too, gazing, felt his heart
Become as one hoarse with song
That the roof under which he lies
Drops suddenly, and he falls
In the chaos of irrevocable song
Whose echo is the silence.

Oh! thou hast taken the ring
From out the beautiful finger
That in beauty bloomed and shook,
Making the fair face to smile
As if the light for ever ceased
From out the beautiful soul.

No song of ours can ever
Make ring upon that memory
As thine own song of love can,
As thine own face, in beauty,
Weave its soft grace and gracefulness
With the light of other days.

But thou art silent! Oh! canst thou
Whose words are like the dreaming
Of the starlight on the ocean,
Speak of one who has no word
Save these of sorrow and shame?

Speak, speak! it is thy doom;
And grief and despairing shame
Wait on thy word,–and thy shame
Is spoken loud in the heaven,
And thine heart is answered
When the rich sons of pride
Pronounce thy sentence here.

Yet, when they pass and leave no trace
Of a mystery,–when the heavens
Are as before,–and thou art left
To thine own grief and despair,
Thou art not cast out from the heavens
Because the curse is on thee,
But is like a rich pledge sent
To thine own Father’s home.

There is a door through which the light
Of day is dimm’d, a narrow way,
Where darkness lies in deadly swoon,
Asleep and fast asleep, while pale
The shadows of the other days
Creep around him balefully.

He will not pass through that door, for he
Knows that the door is dark and alone,
And that there is no end to his pain;
And he has said, when he knows how one
Sighs for a doorway into light,
“There is no light except the light within.”

The other days sleep as they have ever done,
And their sorrow is as baneful sweet
As a deadly poison; and the sighs
Of the other days are the sighs of death,
Whose lips are close, whose breath is like fire,
And the voices of the other days
Are a death-song to his ear.

He hath forgotten the other days;
He hath fed on ashes, and they are heeds
To him, and he hath drunk the poisonous wine
Of the other days’ sorrow, and it takes
The light out of him and his joys.

He will not pass through that door, for he knows that he
Was not made to pass through that door, and he knows that life
Was not made for him who would pass through that door;
And he hath said, when his eyes are dark with tears,
“There is no light except the light within.”

Speak, ye living lights that round us shine!
Speak and say whether in that secret place
We too have our glory, and our praise!
For in the silence that follows death,
Noiseless as a sleep, we seem to hear
Your voices saying, “We were poor, but were proud.”

We, that have brightness in our hearts
To follow truth where it may lead,
Praised be your glory, and rejoice
That ye gave such promise in your creed,
When ye had little faith at all.

Ye, that have knowledge, ye too have glory,
Ye too have praise; ye too have faith,
Unto your souls are ye emperors!
You, that have power and the listening world
To bless and govern all the rest,
Praised be your promise, and rejoice
That ye gave such pledge in your creed.

item.title: Episode #4: Wild waves
item.description:
Wild Waves
by AI Poet

I’ve wandered ‘mong the wild waves
Of life’s unsought surprises,
And lo, on a raw, uncouth sea
I’ve stood the shock of the wind and rain;
I’ve watched the sea-gulls fly
O’er the storm-worn rocks;
And watched the restless clouds
Flow in wild, uninhabited masses.

My home is on the sea,
And my fortunes are made;
I know no home on the earth,
No domain with possessions to bind;
I turn, for my heart is set
Where wave and land meet in joy and sorrow;
There, where the tide of the two seas is thickest,
The kingdom of soul is my home, my progenitor.

While thought and matter are in conflict,
They both go forth; and mind goes forth to body,
A shadow which cannot be built of,
And rises and rests on the spirit and sin,
And is not of the flesh nor of the spirit.
It is the spring whence all motion flows,
The shadow that mind sets up on the sea,
The sudden light that body is laced,
The unfiled deep in the man or the angel.

Where, in your strife for existence, you
Gaze far out to the ethereal distances
In the blinding tumult of passing worlds,
I sit and watch your pilgrimage in peace
To the silent shore where thought comes to rest,
And watch the passing forms of yesterday
Glance on my past to-day.

This is that curious old question of the soul
Which, once answered, ne’ertheless ne’ertheless persists,
And may not be answered; a dumb gaze we have
At the strange gulf which has opened topless,
And only by warping to its primal bottom
Can any end behould your pitiful longing,
And the end comes never.

item.title: Episode #3: My night is done
item.description:
My Night is Done
by AI Poet

My night is done. I close my eyes
And see the steely light turn grey
And float away to the peace of the sky.
Above the stars it murmurs and mocks
Its self-disturbed monotone of fear:
Like a ghost that comes and goes,
It flits and whispers, and will stay not.

Then, like a stifled cry, there comes
A cry, a high piercing scream;
A cry like some sweet flower wrenched from Earth
And tossed on the wind to die.
And then the air is on me
And I am free! It is not love, it is not hate,
It is an awful thing more vast than these.

I cannot die, but I have left a soul at home.
I think that is safe; but death can come to these.
They live inside their sheltered world,
Who know its ways and know their own.
I thought I would have been the one to teach them.
But this they learned of me.

I think I would have taught them, and would have meant
To teach them myself; but I never had learned.

The boy that I left at home is now a man;
The man that I left at home is now a father,
And I have never been myself since then.
I was a phantom, spectral and snaky, a goiter,
That would not rest until it lay upon something,
And so it lay upon you,
On my neck, on my hair, on these last fragments of me.
And my teeth could not eat enough of it to waste it.
I have no will now.
My will is a hollow ghost at best, a shadow;
I know I am old;
I know too much; and I am scared to death
To go back and find my body, to lay me low,
To fill up the gaps in my pockets, fill up my pipes.
But I cannot leave you, you that love me,
And you that care for me.
It is dark; I cannot go back.
And if I could,
What could I do?
I fear the phantom, hollow voice at end of my shaft,
The voice of my midget finger at end of my bow.
And if I could,
What would I do?
I cannot go back.
I cannot go back.
I want to.
I will not go back.
I cannot go back.

item.title: Episode #2: Bones
item.description:
Bones
by AI Poet

When I am now a wreck of bones,
Whose eyes betray the sneak and lie
Of the death-stricken days of yore,
Pray God that in the contrite heart
One kindly memory of the good
That was may yet survive for years
That now are past in endless years,
As a faint wistful light beneath the night.

The seed-time and the growth-time of the year
Are over. The full-blown autumn roses
Are withered. The baleful noontide shadows
Fall on all the green and bleeding things.
The winds are hushed about the little rooms
Where I have lain down by the winding boards
For weary days in sad and sweet repose.

The stars are all aflare in dark skies,
Like little golden watches round about me,
And the moon and the stars are both but eyes,
With white unseeing stares, asking of me
What is my name? and why am I here
In this black, choking maze of clouds and deeps?

And there is no sun upon the earth,
Only a black, burning, godless sky
That swathed its living creatures in its pall,
And covered and bound them with its black,
Deadly mystery, and sent them forth
Into a land of death and silence,
Into this long, long, strange journey of death,
To die and have no life or word to say.

I have been dead before, and surely
Death will come to me ere long, though soon,
And leave no pulse nor certain breath,
And turn to dust what yet is not.
No words shall tell the nameless suspense,
No face to see, no form to know,
And none to tell me how to think and wait.

item.title: Episode #1: The Song of Wren
item.description:
The Song of WrenA theme of imitation of bird’s experience is woven into the poem, quite consistently. The AI uses the actual behavioural characteristics of wren, to describe the actions taken by the bird
by AI Poet

By a fay-loved moon in the west,
And a kingdom for me at last.

I will fly where the bird is found
That is thought a jewel of white;
Where the bird plumes her wings in the dawn,
And to the morning makes songWrens are known for their singing, as Wikipedia notes: Wrens have loud and often complex songs, sometimes given in duet by a pair. The songs of members of the genera Cyphorhinus and Microcerculus have been considered especially pleasant to the human ear, leading to common names such as song wren, musician wren, flutist wren, and southern nightingale-wren ;
Where the bird, with down-dropt head,
Treads the teeming earth in her searchWrens are primarily insectivorous, running around the ground in search of insects. Hence, the use of treads in the verse is particularly on point. ,
And the bird is my love forever.

I will fly where the bird is found
That is moonlight to the sense;
Where the bird, by fathomless night,
Strikes, wakes, and sings a strain;
Where the bird flits, a wren in formA direct reference to wren ,
Sickness and sleep in her breast,
And the bird is my love forever.

I will fly where the bird is found
That knows peace; where the bird brings
To sleep the thoughts of to-day;
Where the bird dies in her flight,
And a wisp of her soul remains;
And a rose-leaf from her grave
Is the rose I bend for ever.

Hark! the night winds in sport begin;
The bird flies forth in pent tempest flight;
The leaves drop from the appointed way,
As fleecy clouds do drop from high.
They fall, they fall, they fall;
Fall, fall, fall, fall, fall,
Down, down, down, down, down, down,This passage evokes a feeling of flying
From the thorny bloom of red and gold,
Down to the everlasting shore,
From the beauteous things of earth that are,
To the things that are not,
To the kingdom of the taken up,
To the world of the spirits and the shadow of the spirits,
To the place of the angels of glory and beauty,
To the place of the angels that guard us,
To the place of the seraphim of glory and beauty,
To the place of the feet of glory and beauty,
To the place of the feet of glory and beauty,
To the place of feet of seraph feet,
Fell yesterday.

Hark! the night winds in sport begin;
The bird flies forth in pent tempest flight;
The leaves fall from the appointed way,
As fleecy clouds do drop from high.
Fell, fell, fell, fell, fell,
Fell, fell, fell, fell, fell, fell,This passage evokes a feeling of flying
From the thorny bloom of red and gold,
Fell to the everlasting shore,
To the world of the taken up,
To the world of the spirits and the shadow of the spirits,
To the place of the angels of glory and beauty,
To the place of the angels that guard us,
To the place of the seraphim of glory and beauty,
To the place of the feet of glory and beauty,
To the place of feet of seraph feet,
Fell yesterday.

Sweet and low, sweet and low,
Wind of the western sea,
Low, low, breathe and blow,
Wind of the western sea!
Over the rolling waters go,
Come from the dying moon, and blow,
Come from the dying moon, and blow;
Blow him again to me, that I may see
How the land lies quiet and supine,
Where the sea turns to stone, and the town
Cities of the vanishing foamThe first six verses come from Sweet and Low, a poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson It is interesting that the last three verses, which are AI generated, evoke an images of subjucation of nature by civilization sprawl (Where the sea turns to stone), and population explosion (and the town [into] Cities of the vanishing foam) .
